read in your paper cure tor drunkards;
a few grains of tartar emetic, ipecac and as
safetida, which obtained and mixed with
his favourite brandy. A few weeks ago he
released me from confinement one evening,
and having seen no person for six hours,
was happy even to see him--"well my love"
says !, .yol are home earlier than usual
have been very lonesome" $50 much the
BETTER" says he, YOU women are ever chat
.ering and Cabling when you are together;
always scandalizng your neighbours, and
finding fault with your husbands" 'But
my DEAR" said l, with great mildness, "you
know that sometimes the affectionate solici-
tude Of a wife may plead her excuse for be-


ing troublesome. ."--"Oh bah, don't talk to
me, you're fool" So saying, he rose up,
went to the sde,nard, and took copious
draught of the brandy mixture, which he
repeated in ten minutes, and sat down to
read the paper. In a short .ime he began
to make a variety of wry faces, puckered
his mouth, squinted awfully, wrinkled his
face, and forthwith the dose operated as ef-
frctually as a chanccllor's injunction. i pit
led him all night but desperate cases
require desperate remedies. Next day he
felt quite easy; the tone of his stomach was
improved; he shrunk from the brandy bet
.


liquors to excess, produced bile on the ssom-


ach, and lie would renounce it for ever. lie
has not touched liquor since, ard there IS
an evident improvement in his health, per
son and manners On Saturday one OF his
topping friends just called in, to say u hope
| | don't intrut,e," tell long story, and occa-
sionally moisten his lips with glassot the in-
junction brandy, which stood on the side
board. Thinks / to myself" you will have
spasms shortly--.fIe left rs aftera third and
fourth glass, and learn that he likwise .re-
nounces the devil and all his works" having |
been powerfully moved. ! have just COM
mcnced upon third pcrscn.


Thus you see my dear Mr.. Editor, that
your receipt has been of ncalculable benefit


to disconsolate wife, who has seen her
husband daily undermining his health, vast
ing his resources, brutalizing his habits and
manners, and neglerting III, family.

Monday, Ian. 2e.--In the Senate, about
three hours and half were spent IN the
consideration Of Executive business. A bill
was reported from the Committee on Com
merce, for regulating the commercial inter.
course between the United States and the
colonies of Great Britain. The bill from the
House of Representatives appropriating
twenty thousand dollars for the relief ofthe
sufferers by the late fire a, Alexandria, was
twice read


In the House of Representatives, the dis
cussion on Mr.. Ruchannan's motion to dis
charge the Committee from the further
cor sderation Of the Manufacturers bill was
resumed, but without coming To any result
The bill making provision for the officers
OF the army OF the revolution went into com
mittcc, and an amendment was proposed by
Mr.. Condict, proposing one thousand dollars
each as gratnity 10 the officers, and an an
nuitv for life; but the committee rose with
out proceeding further, and the amendment
was ordered to be printed.


In the Senate, on Tuesday, bill was re
ported from the Judiciary Committee for
the appointment of a commission. for the
distribution among the claimants under the
first article of the Treaty of Ghent, for slaves
and other property taken away by the Brit
ish after the signing Of that treaty. Of
the sums which shall be awarded to them
respectively.


The bill appropriating 10000 dollars Tor
the relief of the INDECENT sufferers by the
late fire in Alexandria, was read a third time
and passed.


The consideration of the Bankrupt bill
was resumed, and the motion of Mr. Branch.
to strike out the 93d Section, was further
discussed.


In the House of representatives, the dis
cusson ON Mr.. Ruchannn's motion to dis
charge the Committee from the further con
sideration of the Manufacturers bill wa, re-
sumed. The motion was gatiyed-aycs 81;
noes 113.


In the Senate, on "Wednesday. the consid
Grafton of the Bankrupt bill was resumed.
the motion 10 strike out the 93d Section still
pending. Mr.. Berrien opposed the motion.
and Mr., Woodbury. and Mr.. razewell sup
ported it.


In the House of Representatives, a bill
was reported BY Mr.. Storrs, from the Com
mittee on Naval Affairs, to authorize the
building of two schooners tor the naval SER
vice, and for the rebuilding the Noosuch.


The bill Tor the relief of the New-York
and pennsylvania lnstitutinns Tor the Deaf
and Dumb, WAS taken mp, on motion Of Mr..
Wurts, but it WIS, after some discussion.
committed TO the Committee on Public lands.
win Instructions 70 consider the Dropfietv of
making a grant of a township to all the
states which have not already received
lands for literary or other institutions. This
commitment, it is presumed will kill the
bill.


In the Senate, on Thursday, the consdc
ration of the Bankrupt bill was resumed.
The motion of Mr.. Branch to strike out the
93d section, which provides for the volnnta-
ry bankruptcy of persons other than traders.
was further discussed and rejected.


The House of Representatives were en-
gagged in the discussion Of the Manufacture
cr's Bill, in Committee of the Whole on the
state OF the Union, without coming to anv
result. Mr.. lngham spoke at length against
It; and on motion of Mr.. Pearce the Com
mittec rose.


In the Senate, on Friday, the considera-
ton OF the Bankrupt bill was resumed. Mr.
heed opposed the bill in speech of about
two hours length, and moved an amendment
to the first section of the bill, providing that
Notwithstanding the bill should be construed
to extend to contracts made previous to the
passage OF tins bill. The amendment was
rejected; ayes l6, noes 80. MIR. Barton
moved the reconsideration OF the motion to
strike out the 93d section. Mr.. Barton's
motion was not acted on, as the Senate ad-
journed.


In the House of Representatives, an un-
successful attempt was made to bring up
the Manufacturers bill, and also the bill to
make provision for the surviving officers of
the army of the revolution. The PROPOSE
tons were defeated on the ground that
FRIDAY and Saturday are, by rule of the
House, considered as days on which private

Dear Mr.. Editor.-You must know that 7
am blessed with a tipping husband-not one
who gets roaring drunk and falls lifeless on
the bed and snores out the night, but one of
your soaking fellows. who TOPICS necessarily.
never gets positively drunk, but is always
brutal in his cups, and has a very awkward
mode of locking me up whenever he intends
wetting his jacksy. While Thus confined, ]
From the Ne,c- York Eno,t;rer

bills have preference, unless ordered 9th
erwise by the House. The regulation was
enforced; in consequence Of which about

the whole. and ordered to be engrossed and
read third time tomorrow.

his favorite object; and the year 1878 and
part of 1879, were employed in painting the
Sortic from Gibraltar, which was hnished
and exhibited iu London intMay, 1889, with
general appreciation. This picture had
surface Of feet by g exactly the fourth
part of the size of those now iii the Capitol;
and the artist was offered for it at the time.
and refused, 1900 guineas, equal to S5592.
The small preparatory study, 20 inches BY
so, was afterwards purchased by Sir Fran.
els Barring, who paid for it 500 guineas, e.
DUAL to $3.50 dollars, and is now in the pos
session of his son Alexander Barring, Esq i'll
London.


This work established the reputation of
the artist in Europe, and he might have pur-
sued his profession in London or Paris, with
the farest prospect Of success; but the mo-
ment for which he had waited was arrived
the present constitution of the United States
was adopted.-Washingto was President,
and many of the early patriots and heroes OF
the revolution were re-assembled in the va
rious departments of the new government;
the country wasin prosperity, and every Cir
cumstance concurred to favor his original
plan.


We find him therefore returning to Amer
ica in November, 1885, passing the win
ter in New York, which was then the seat
of government, and there procuring many
portraits of distinguished men, civil and mill
tary, to be introduced in the course of his
great work.


Thus far he had proceeded in his object.
without patronage, public CT private, with
devotion, which, in the estimation Of many
of his friends, bordered on insane enthusiasm.
In April, 1890, he published, in New York,
q prospectus of his intended work, and
solicited subscriptions for the prints of Bun
kers Hill and Quebec, which were alrea.
DIV in progress in the hands Of eminent en-
gravers.


The work now received substantial pat
ronagc--and in the course ot three years the
names of subscribers amounted 10 nearly
500; !. sum, however, not quite sufficient 70
cover the expense Of engraving the two
plates, each was contracted for at the price
of one thousand guineas, equal to 1866 dol
lars.


Col Trumbull remained in America until
Nav, 1894, during which time he travelled
from. New Hampshire to South Carolina,
every where endeavouring to obtain pnr-
traits of the distinguished men who had
been actors in those subjects which he had
selected, as well as views OF the place.
which had been the scenes of the several
actions; and had, in great measure, COM
pleted his collection of materials for the en-
tire work.


During this period, the French revolution
commenced with promise OF results which,
were most lamentably defeated; and ms
ing in its course to a moral and political
tornado, threatened to sweep before it all
established institutions, and to reduce hui
man society to its original elements. The
arts Of peace disappeared before the spi-
Tit OF war Europe became an immense
camp; and America hardly escaped being
involved in the universal desolaton of the
tempest.


In MAY. 1894, Mr. Jay was appointed Min
ister Penpotentarv to Great Britain; and
we find Col. Trumhul accompanying him in
the character Of Secretary.


In 1896 he received from President Wash
ington a commission TO reside in London, as
agent for the recovery of impressed seamen,
which he declined, in consequence of having
Deen appointed, in the manner provided by
the treaty, the fifth of that board of COM
missioners who were authorized TO carry in
to effect the 9TH article of the treaty, which
respected irregular OF illegal captures, one
of the most important objects of the negotia-
tion of Mr.. Jay.


This commission brought their arduous
labours to an honourable conclusion in the
spring OF 1904, when the artist returned to
the United States to witness new and un-
suspicious state ofpublc affairs. The demon
of party discord had sunk the character of
Americans in the patry distinctions of Brit
isb or French partizans, and it would have
been idle at such time and in such an alb
sence OF all national feeling to persevere in
his work of the Revolution. The project,
therefore, slept, until. in happier moment,
that joint resolution Of the two Houses of
Congress was passed, which authorised the
painting of those four subjects, which are
now placed in what may, with proprety,
be called, in future, the Hal cftAe Revolu-
tion.


In those four paintings, this nation possess
es which no other nation Of people have yet
possessed. Il is our peculiar fate to have
sprung into existence under circum stances
as singular in their nature, as the result has
been glorious Our infant years are not only
distinguished by the rugged virtues of war
but by the polished elegancies Of the arts of
peace; ard through the perseverance Of orc
man, which we believe has no parallel, dis
tant posterity will be able to view the { f.ith
full representations of those to whose hardi-
hood they stand indebted for their proud in
heritance.


We are happy to learn from the proceed
ings of the House of Repre- sentatiges, that
there is an intention to fill the remaining
vacant spaces in the grand Hail with other

Caution.-Four children of citizen :.
the north part of Boston, narrowly escapsd
their lives on Friday morning last. In ron.
sequence ofthe extreme cold weather ryo,.
mer OF Goals, was placed in the room whsr.
these children slept. 1t was not char,oci
but the Goals of common zvood fire. bbon,
one O'Clock they were all taken with yoms
itng, except one, who was requested to II.
form their parents of the illness Of then
brothers. Through an all wise Providence
he was enabled to reach the chamber Of Nj
parents; and to inform them that all the
children in the chamber, were taken III
when he Immediately tainted. The parents
instantly repaired to the chamber, epened
the door, dragged them out of the chamber
and thus in the moment of danger rescued
the four children from an untimely end.
This will be warning to all persons not to
place fire in the middle of room where the
Fireplace is closed; as they in all cases will
hazard the lives of those who sleep in the
room.


A Grey Eagle was shot by sportsman on
Mason's Island at the mouth of Mystick ry.
er, near Stonington, Comm last week. He
was fired at three times before he Welded
and on being brought to the ground, it wa,
discovered that he had steel trap attached
to one of his toes, which had probably been
in that situation for considerable length Of
time, as the toe below where the trap held
was dead The Eagle measured about eight
feet from the tip of one wing to that Of the
other.


A very singular and affecting incident oc.
Cured in one of the legislative houses of n.
Sarolina. few days ago. John Stanley,
Esq. speaker OF the house of commons, a
gentleman well remembered as an able mem.
Der OF congress several years ago, and one Of
the most distinguished citizens Of his native
state, while in the discharge ofthe duties Of
the chair, and in the enjoyment of health,
was suddenly prostrated by paralytic af
fection, which deprived him of the powerof
speech or motion. He was carried to his
lodgings, where he still lies, incapable 0!
moving. General James Iredell was ap-
pointed speaker of the house protempore.


SOMETHING NEW.


notwithstanding the icy embrace Of win.
ter (says the Bedford Co. Pa. Republican,
which is congealing all around us, and the
cold teecy garment is wide spread-little
Cupid, with ne'er blanket, is playing the
most antic tricks upon his pretty game
Last week young Mr.. and Miss, of Waylu
sing township, having each received a
wound from the little archer without dan.
gerous delay, applied to justice for re-
ceipt For some reason, this antidote was
denied them; but not to be foled in this
manner, they resolved upon an expcdmentt
winch is directly opposed to the interest OF
the Esquire--this is, to marry themselves,
they each recited the marriage contract, and
assented to its VOWS in the presence OF many
witnesses. 1t %as pronounced a fair bargain,
and they are determined to abide by it.

days since gentleman of Three Rivers,
skated from that town to Berthier, distance
OF forty five miles, in five hours. It's added
that on the 9th of January 1924, Mr.. Arll'
y Hart. son of Moses Hart. Esq. Of Three
Rivers, skated the same distance in ieAf
hours and forty three minutes.

The packet ship Edward Bonafe, Capt. Funk,
arrived at New-York, on Friday last, sailed from
Havrc on the 10Th December, and brings Paris
papers of the 18th.


The intelligence Of the steps taken BY Great
Britain in aid OF Portugal was received in Paris
on the 18th, and created considerable sensation,
causing fall in Funds, but they advanced again
the next day TO within one per cent of their
previous rates. We have seen several letters
from Iiayre of the 18th, all of which concur in
the opinion that warwill not ensue. One writer
says, "0ur ministes are strongly attached to
their places, and they know that they would be
hurled from them in twenty four hours if they
were to take that step" Another says, that
France and England understand each other per.
fectly well, and will avoid rupture Letters
from Lisbon Of the 9th received at iiavre, men
toned that the Portuguese insurgents had been
beaten by the militia of the Country.


There is nothing later from England The
news Of the sending of troops to Portugal, with
Mr.. Cannng's speech, &c. has just reached Paris
and the public were awaiting with great solci-
tutle, to see what course the French government
would adopt. 1t appears that the concluding
passage in the address Of Charles 10th, in which
he ref,rs to the French arms, had caused great
fall in the funds in Paris and the first report of
the measures in England, produced panic; but
the declaration IN the speech of the King of
England, of the favorable disposition of the pow
crs to the preservation Of peace, had caused a
rise. 1t is now reported that the concluding
passage WAS inserted in the French Kings
speech, in consequence Of the keeper of the
seals having suddenly deserted NJ. Vele and
taken sides against the pacific party. A private
letter from Raronne, states, that the troops
were to be Withdrawn from Spain, to avoid coun-
tenancing the invasion OF Portugal but there ap-
pears to be nothing certain in these various rll-
mo'irs.


The party il France called the Congre cation,
arc considered rs going hand in hand with the
ultra party in Spain, being incline,lto war with
England, and having hopes Of exciting diver
sion in ireland.


The Chamber Of Deputies was to be opened
on the 18th Dec. but after several calls, the re.
qGsltc number for session not being present,
it did not take place.


GREEC E.-A letter dated Napoli, Oct. 18th
says:--An English vessel which arrived ycstcr.
day ron Constantiuoplc, brought to the Com
mittce ofthc National Assembly, (thc Committee
Of Ihirtecn,) letter from Mr. S. Canning, in
which that minister informs them--.That lie has
received the instructions he expected, touching
an arrangement between the Porte and Greece,
and that they contained precise orders to make
to the Turkish ministry, propositions founded on
the demands of The Greeks; that the negotiations
between Russia and the Porte, were to be con.
c'nded on the 7ti of Oct. and that he would
take care to make known the result to the mem
bers ot the committees and that in case of an
amic@ble arrangement between the two empires,
the Russian Ambassador would proceed immcdi.

sPAIN---Madrid dates to Dec. 4th on which
day his Majesty rode into the town smoking Sc
gar with quite an air; certain sign of his being
in good health.


PORTUGAL.-Repot says that Lord Beres.
ford is to take the command of the porturtiese
troops. He had had several conferences with
the minister at war, and it was determined that
the army should be put on the same footing as
it was twelve years ago.

read in your paper cure tor drunkards;
a few grains of tartar emetic, ipecac and as
safetida, which obtained and mixed with
his favourite brandy. A few weeks ago he
released me from confinement one evening,
and having seen no person for six hours,
was happy even to see him--"well my love"
says !, .yol are home earlier than usual
have been very lonesome" $50 much the
BETTER" says he, YOU women are ever chat
.ering and Cabling when you are together;
always scandalizng your neighbours, and
finding fault with your husbands" 'But
my DEAR" said l, with great mildness, "you
know that sometimes the affectionate solici-
tude Of a wife may plead her excuse for be-


ing troublesome. ."--"Oh bah, don't talk to
me, you're fool" So saying, he rose up,
went to the sde,nard, and took copious
draught of the brandy mixture, which he
repeated in ten minutes, and sat down to
read the paper. In a short .ime he began
to make a variety of wry faces, puckered
his mouth, squinted awfully, wrinkled his
face, and forthwith the dose operated as ef-
frctually as a chanccllor's injunction. i pit
led him all night but desperate cases
require desperate remedies. Next day he
felt quite easy; the tone of his stomach was
improved; he shrunk from the brandy bet
.


liquors to excess, produced bile on the ssom-


ach, and lie would renounce it for ever. lie
has not touched liquor since, ard there IS
an evident improvement in his health, per
son and manners On Saturday one OF his
topping friends just called in, to say u hope
| | don't intrut,e," tell long story, and occa-
sionally moisten his lips with glassot the in-
junction brandy, which stood on the side
board. Thinks / to myself" you will have
spasms shortly--.fIe left rs aftera third and
fourth glass, and learn that he likwise .re-
nounces the devil and all his works" having |
been powerfully moved. ! have just COM
mcnced upon third pcrscn.


Thus you see my dear Mr.. Editor, that
your receipt has been of ncalculable benefit


to disconsolate wife, who has seen her
husband daily undermining his health, vast
ing his resources, brutalizing his habits and
manners, and neglerting III, family.

by the fire at Alexandria.

merica ~ Congress .fssembied, That the

is hereby, appropriated, to be paid out of any
money in the Treasury not otherwise appropri.
ated, for the relief of the INDECENT sufferers by
the destructive fire in the city of Alexandra, in
the District of Columbia, to be distributed under

RESOLUTION directing the Secretary of the


Navy to apply to the Government Of Pennsyl-


yania for Jurisdiction over certain lands at the


Navy Yard, Philadelphia.


Resotred By the Senate and House Of
REPRESENTATIVES IF The United States Of H.
mcrica in Congress assembled, That the
Secretary of the Navy be directed to request
the Government of the State of Pennsylvania to
cede to the United States jurisdiction over such
lands as are owned by the United States, and i'm.
proved for public purposes, at the Navy Yard
near Philadelphia.


Approved: Jan. "a, 1927.

CONGREsS.--2 SESSION

cohP1LED FRoN THE NATIONAL JorRSAL


Monday, Ian. 2e.--In the Senate, about
three hours and half were spent IN the
consideration Of Executive business. A bill
was reported from the Committee on Com
merce, for regulating the commercial inter.
course between the United States and the
colonies of Great Britain. The bill from the
House of Representatives appropriating
twenty thousand dollars for the relief ofthe
sufferers by the late fire a, Alexandria, was
twice read


In the House of Representatives, the dis
cussion on Mr.. Ruchannan's motion to dis
charge the Committee from the further
cor sderation Of the Manufacturers bill was
resumed, but without coming To any result
The bill making provision for the officers
OF the army OF the revolution went into com
mittcc, and an amendment was proposed by
Mr.. Condict, proposing one thousand dollars
each as gratnity 10 the officers, and an an
nuitv for life; but the committee rose with
out proceeding further, and the amendment
was ordered to be printed.


In the Senate, on Tuesday, bill was re
ported from the Judiciary Committee for
the appointment of a commission. for the
distribution among the claimants under the
first article of the Treaty of Ghent, for slaves
and other property taken away by the Brit
ish after the signing Of that treaty. Of
the sums which shall be awarded to them
respectively.


The bill appropriating 10000 dollars Tor
the relief of the INDECENT sufferers by the
late fire in Alexandria, was read a third time
and passed.


The consideration of the Bankrupt bill
was resumed, and the motion of Mr. Branch.
to strike out the 93d Section, was further
discussed.


In the House of representatives, the dis
cusson ON Mr.. Ruchannn's motion to dis
charge the Committee from the further con
sideration of the Manufacturers bill wa, re-
sumed. The motion was gatiyed-aycs 81;
noes 113.


In the Senate, on "Wednesday. the consid
Grafton of the Bankrupt bill was resumed.
the motion 10 strike out the 93d Section still
pending. Mr.. Berrien opposed the motion.
and Mr., Woodbury. and Mr.. razewell sup
ported it.


In the House of Representatives, a bill
was reported BY Mr.. Storrs, from the Com
mittee on Naval Affairs, to authorize the
building of two schooners tor the naval SER
vice, and for the rebuilding the Noosuch.


The bill Tor the relief of the New-York
and pennsylvania lnstitutinns Tor the Deaf
and Dumb, WAS taken mp, on motion Of Mr..
Wurts, but it WIS, after some discussion.
committed TO the Committee on Public lands.
win Instructions 70 consider the Dropfietv of
making a grant of a township to all the
states which have not already received
lands for literary or other institutions. This
commitment, it is presumed will kill the
bill.


In the Senate, on Thursday, the consdc
ration of the Bankrupt bill was resumed.
The motion of Mr.. Branch to strike out the
93d section, which provides for the volnnta-
ry bankruptcy of persons other than traders.
was further discussed and rejected.


The House of Representatives were en-
gagged in the discussion Of the Manufacture
cr's Bill, in Committee of the Whole on the
state OF the Union, without coming to anv
result. Mr.. lngham spoke at length against
It; and on motion of Mr.. Pearce the Com
mittec rose.


In the Senate, on Friday, the considera-
ton OF the Bankrupt bill was resumed. Mr.
heed opposed the bill in speech of about
two hours length, and moved an amendment
to the first section of the bill, providing that
Notwithstanding the bill should be construed
to extend to contracts made previous to the
passage OF tins bill. The amendment was
rejected; ayes l6, noes 80. MIR. Barton
moved the reconsideration OF the motion to
strike out the 93d section. Mr.. Barton's
motion was not acted on, as the Senate ad-
journed.


In the House of Representatives, an un-
successful attempt was made to bring up
the Manufacturers bill, and also the bill to
make provision for the surviving officers of
the army of the revolution. The PROPOSE
tons were defeated on the ground that
FRIDAY and Saturday are, by rule of the
House, considered as days on which private

full articles.headline: From the Ne,c- York Eno,t;rer
full articles.article:
Dear Mr.. Editor.-You must know that 7
am blessed with a tipping husband-not one
who gets roaring drunk and falls lifeless on
the bed and snores out the night, but one of
your soaking fellows. who TOPICS necessarily.
never gets positively drunk, but is always
brutal in his cups, and has a very awkward
mode of locking me up whenever he intends
wetting his jacksy. While Thus confined, ]

bills have preference, unless ordered 9th
erwise by the House. The regulation was
enforced; in consequence Of which about
seven bills were acted on in Committee OF
the whole. and ordered to be engrossed and
read third time tomorrow.

his favorite object; and the year 1878 and
part of 1879, were employed in painting the
Sortic from Gibraltar, which was hnished
and exhibited iu London intMay, 1889, with
general appreciation. This picture had
surface Of feet by g exactly the fourth
part of the size of those now iii the Capitol;
and the artist was offered for it at the time.
and refused, 1900 guineas, equal to S5592.
The small preparatory study, 20 inches BY
so, was afterwards purchased by Sir Fran.
els Barring, who paid for it 500 guineas, e.
DUAL to $3.50 dollars, and is now in the pos
session of his son Alexander Barring, Esq i'll
London.


This work established the reputation of
the artist in Europe, and he might have pur-
sued his profession in London or Paris, with
the farest prospect Of success; but the mo-
ment for which he had waited was arrived
the present constitution of the United States
was adopted.-Washingto was President,
and many of the early patriots and heroes OF
the revolution were re-assembled in the va
rious departments of the new government;
the country wasin prosperity, and every Cir
cumstance concurred to favor his original
plan.


We find him therefore returning to Amer
ica in November, 1885, passing the win
ter in New York, which was then the seat
of government, and there procuring many
portraits of distinguished men, civil and mill
tary, to be introduced in the course of his
great work.


Thus far he had proceeded in his object.
without patronage, public CT private, with
devotion, which, in the estimation Of many
of his friends, bordered on insane enthusiasm.
In April, 1890, he published, in New York,
q prospectus of his intended work, and
solicited subscriptions for the prints of Bun
kers Hill and Quebec, which were alrea.
DIV in progress in the hands Of eminent en-
gravers.


The work now received substantial pat
ronagc--and in the course ot three years the
names of subscribers amounted 10 nearly
500; !. sum, however, not quite sufficient 70
cover the expense Of engraving the two
plates, each was contracted for at the price
of one thousand guineas, equal to 1866 dol
lars.


Col Trumbull remained in America until
Nav, 1894, during which time he travelled
from. New Hampshire to South Carolina,
every where endeavouring to obtain pnr-
traits of the distinguished men who had
been actors in those subjects which he had
selected, as well as views OF the place.
which had been the scenes of the several
actions; and had, in great measure, COM
pleted his collection of materials for the en-
tire work.


During this period, the French revolution
commenced with promise OF results which,
were most lamentably defeated; and ms
ing in its course to a moral and political
tornado, threatened to sweep before it all
established institutions, and to reduce hui
man society to its original elements. The
arts Of peace disappeared before the spi-
Tit OF war Europe became an immense
camp; and America hardly escaped being
involved in the universal desolaton of the
tempest.


In MAY. 1894, Mr. Jay was appointed Min
ister Penpotentarv to Great Britain; and
we find Col. Trumhul accompanying him in
the character Of Secretary.


In 1896 he received from President Wash
ington a commission TO reside in London, as
agent for the recovery of impressed seamen,
which he declined, in consequence of having
Deen appointed, in the manner provided by
the treaty, the fifth of that board of COM
missioners who were authorized TO carry in
to effect the 9TH article of the treaty, which
respected irregular OF illegal captures, one
of the most important objects of the negotia-
tion of Mr.. Jay.


This commission brought their arduous
labours to an honourable conclusion in the
spring OF 1904, when the artist returned to
the United States to witness new and un-
suspicious state ofpublc affairs. The demon
of party discord had sunk the character of
Americans in the patry distinctions of Brit
isb or French partizans, and it would have
been idle at such time and in such an alb
sence OF all national feeling to persevere in
his work of the Revolution. The project,
therefore, slept, until. in happier moment,
that joint resolution Of the two Houses of
Congress was passed, which authorised the
painting of those four subjects, which are
now placed in what may, with proprety,
be called, in future, the Hal cftAe Revolu-
tion.


In those four paintings, this nation possess
es which no other nation Of people have yet
possessed. Il is our peculiar fate to have
sprung into existence under circum stances
as singular in their nature, as the result has
been glorious Our infant years are not only
distinguished by the rugged virtues of war
but by the polished elegancies Of the arts of
peace; ard through the perseverance Of orc
man, which we believe has no parallel, dis
tant posterity will be able to view the { f.ith
full representations of those to whose hardi-
hood they stand indebted for their proud in
heritance.


We are happy to learn from the proceed
ings of the House of Repre- sentatiges, that
there is an intention to fill the remaining
vacant spaces in the grand Hail with other

PrBLIc-No. ,.

Caution.-Four children of citizen :.
the north part of Boston, narrowly escapsd
their lives on Friday morning last. In ron.
sequence ofthe extreme cold weather ryo,.
mer OF Goals, was placed in the room whsr.
these children slept. 1t was not char,oci
but the Goals of common zvood fire. bbon,
one O'Clock they were all taken with yoms
itng, except one, who was requested to II.
form their parents of the illness Of then
brothers. Through an all wise Providence
he was enabled to reach the chamber Of Nj
parents; and to inform them that all the
children in the chamber, were taken III
when he Immediately tainted. The parents
instantly repaired to the chamber, epened
the door, dragged them out of the chamber
and thus in the moment of danger rescued
the four children from an untimely end.
This will be warning to all persons not to
place fire in the middle of room where the
Fireplace is closed; as they in all cases will
hazard the lives of those who sleep in the
room.


A Grey Eagle was shot by sportsman on
Mason's Island at the mouth of Mystick ry.
er, near Stonington, Comm last week. He
was fired at three times before he Welded
and on being brought to the ground, it wa,
discovered that he had steel trap attached
to one of his toes, which had probably been
in that situation for considerable length Of
time, as the toe below where the trap held
was dead The Eagle measured about eight
feet from the tip of one wing to that Of the
other.


A very singular and affecting incident oc.
Cured in one of the legislative houses of n.
Sarolina. few days ago. John Stanley,
Esq. speaker OF the house of commons, a
gentleman well remembered as an able mem.
Der OF congress several years ago, and one Of
the most distinguished citizens Of his native
state, while in the discharge ofthe duties Of
the chair, and in the enjoyment of health,
was suddenly prostrated by paralytic af
fection, which deprived him of the powerof
speech or motion. He was carried to his
lodgings, where he still lies, incapable 0!
moving. General James Iredell was ap-
pointed speaker of the house protempore.


SOMETHING NEW.


notwithstanding the icy embrace Of win.
ter (says the Bedford Co. Pa. Republican,
which is congealing all around us, and the
cold teecy garment is wide spread-little
Cupid, with ne'er blanket, is playing the
most antic tricks upon his pretty game
Last week young Mr.. and Miss, of Waylu
sing township, having each received a
wound from the little archer without dan.
gerous delay, applied to justice for re-
ceipt For some reason, this antidote was

The packet ship Edward Bonafe, Capt. Funk,
arrived at New-York, on Friday last, sailed from
Havrc on the 10Th December, and brings Paris
papers of the 18th.


The intelligence Of the steps taken BY Great
Britain in aid OF Portugal was received in Paris
on the 18th, and created considerable sensation,
causing fall in Funds, but they advanced again
the next day TO within one per cent of their
previous rates. We have seen several letters
from Iiayre of the 18th, all of which concur in
the opinion that warwill not ensue. One writer
says, "0ur ministes are strongly attached to
their places, and they know that they would be
hurled from them in twenty four hours if they
were to take that step" Another says, that
France and England understand each other per.
fectly well, and will avoid rupture Letters
from Lisbon Of the 9th received at iiavre, men
toned that the Portuguese insurgents had been
beaten by the militia of the Country.


There is nothing later from England The
news Of the sending of troops to Portugal, with
Mr.. Cannng's speech, &c. has just reached Paris
and the public were awaiting with great solci-
tutle, to see what course the French government
would adopt. 1t appears that the concluding
passage in the address Of Charles 10th, in which
he ref,rs to the French arms, had caused great
fall in the funds in Paris and the first report of
the measures in England, produced panic; but
the declaration IN the speech of the King of
England, of the favorable disposition of the pow
crs to the preservation Of peace, had caused a
rise. 1t is now reported that the concluding
passage WAS inserted in the French Kings
speech, in consequence Of the keeper of the
seals having suddenly deserted NJ. Vele and
taken sides against the pacific party. A private
letter from Raronne, states, that the troops
were to be Withdrawn from Spain, to avoid coun-
tenancing the invasion OF Portugal but there ap-
pears to be nothing certain in these various rll-
mo'irs.


The party il France called the Congre cation,
arc considered rs going hand in hand with the
ultra party in Spain, being incline,lto war with
England, and having hopes Of exciting diver
sion in ireland.


The Chamber Of Deputies was to be opened
on the 18th Dec. but after several calls, the re.
qGsltc number for session not being present,
it did not take place.

sPAIN---Madrid dates to Dec. 4th on which
day his Majesty rode into the town smoking Sc
gar with quite an air; certain sign of his being
in good health.


PORTUGAL.-Repot says that Lord Beres.
ford is to take the command of the porturtiese
troops. He had had several conferences with
the minister at war, and it was determined that
the army should be put on the same footing as
it was twelve years ago.

a Grey Eagle was shot by sportsman on
Mason's Island at the mouth of Mystick rv.
er, near Stonington, Conn., last week. He
was fired at three times before he Welded
and on being brought TO the ground, it wa,
discovered that he had a steel trap attached
to one OF his toes, which had probably been
in that situation for considerable length Of
time, as the toe below where the trap held
was dead. The Eagle measured about eight
feet from the tip of one wing to that Of the
other.
